subject: Eradicate eventlet and fix bug lp:959221
commit_message:
Eradicate eventlet and fix bug lp:959221

The bug is simple: whenever swift uploads to a Swift with SSL,
it uses 100% CPU. It happens because we use HTTPSConnection from
eventlet that loops like that, while holding the interpreter lock.

Now, it could be fixed in eventlet, but let's try something more
natural: drop the eventlet's HTTP client. We do not use green
threads in the client anymore, so it's not like we need it for that.

Note that in most cases clients do not use the BufferedHTTPConnection
either, because it's only installed on Swift server nodes, not on
workstations. Get rid of that too.

subject: Allow 2 TempURL keys per account.
commit_message:
Allow 2 TempURL keys per account.

This allows users to rotate their TempURL keys without invalidating
all existing signed URLs. This is handy if you have multiple systems
generating signed URLs, but you want to change your keys for some
reason (e.g. keys compromised, company policy, general paranoia).

Both the first and second keys are optional, so existing accounts'
signed URLs will continue to work as before.

This commit does change the memcache key used to store the fetched
TempURL keys. This is because we were storing the old key as a string
in memcached, but the new one is a list of keys. Since the key cache
lifetime here is only 60 seconds, it doesn't seem like too big a deal
to completely flush the TempURL cache.

Also, this commit adds caching of a negative TempURL result. If the
account HEAD reveals no TempURL keys at all, that result is now stored
for 60 seconds the same way that a positive result would be.

subject: Added ssync option for object replicator
commit_message:
Added ssync option for object replicator

This is just part one of likely many to implement
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/swift/+spec/object-replicator2

I'm doing my best to alter as little as possible, especially in the
unit tests. This is both to keep the review-patch to a minimum and to
ensure I don't introduce bugs the tests would've caught had I not
touched them. This does mean that some code that has moved modules
have not had their tests moved too. Also, some code may not be
exactly where or exactly formatted like we might want it eventually.
I'd like to leave such refactors to follow-on patches to keep this
one as small and confident as possible.

Here's an overview of what I changed and added:

Moved Functionality: To avoid circular imports

    Moved tpool_reraise from swift.obj.replicator to swift.common.utils.

    Moved get_hashes, HASH_FILE, hash_suffix, invalidate_hash,
    ONE_WEEK, PICKLE_PROTOCOL, quarantine_renamer from
    swift.obj.replicator to swift.obj.server.

Moved Config Items:

    Moved the conn_timeout, disk_chunk_size, network_chunk_size, and
    node_timeout configuration items in object-server.conf to the
    [DEFAULT] section so both the object-server and object-replicator
    (and any others) have access to them.

Object Replicator Changes:

    Renamed sync to rsync and made a new sync method that calls a
    configurable sync method.

    Created a new EXPERIMENTAL ssync method that works just like the
    rsync method but uses Swift-only functionality. This sends
    objects over using HTTP-based REPLICATION calls to the remote
    object server. REPLICATION calls are just a form of request
    pipelining for speed and to allow the remote host to more easily
    limit incoming replication.

Object Server Changes:

    Added new IterFile to change an iter into a file-like object that
    can be used as wsgi.input.

    Added REPLICATION method to accept new ssync type requests.

subject: Doubling the ring
commit_message:
Doubling the ring

This patch adds support for ring size changes.
More specifically it allows to increase (but not decrease)
the ring by doubling every partition.

Doubling the ring changes the partition numbers meaning that
it may affect the directory structure of the a/c/o servers.
To overcome this, the patch includes the following additional
changes:
* The ring now holds a part_power per device which will never be changed.
* The storage_directory was changed to offer a stable path based on the
the device part_power
* The db_replicators were adjusted such that they find nodes based on
the hash used as part of the db path
* The object replicators were adjusted to hold multiple hash lists
per HASH FILE
* The object REPLICATE was extended to include a new header
carrying the sender's ring part_power.

This patch is fully backwards compatible.
The only change made to an existing installation is progressing the
HASH FILE to a new format without rehashing of objects.

The patch supports gradually upgrading existing installations to become
ready for a future ring doubling event.

Implements: blueprint ring-doubling

This patch shows an alternate way of fixing the atomic
identity modifications to allow drivers that are capable
of transactions to implement them as needed.

Basically, this required pulling code calls out of the
controller layer and into the underlying drivers. The
pattern to follow to allow transactional drivers to issue
appropriate session handling is to ensure each main

that outer transactions can be contained, if the driver
supports it.

subject: Copy Nova's workaround for RHEL6 eventlet issue
commit_message:
Copy Nova's workaround for RHEL6 eventlet issue

The eventlet on PyPI basically doesn't work on RHEL because we (Red Hat)
screwed up by not taking monkey patching into account when backporting
an API from python 3. This is the series of events:

  1) We backported a patch to RHEL6 from Python 3 which added an
     optional 'timeout' argument to subprocess.Popen:

       http://pkgs.devel.redhat.com/cgit/rpms/python/commit/?h=rhel-6.3&id=fc9a3f0e07

     This might sound innocuous but it means the wait() function get
     called with a timeout argument

  2) eventlet overrides this function, but doesn't know about the
     timeout argument, so it fails. To reproduce, try applying this to
     your python 2.7:

       https://gist.github.com/markmc/5500967

  3) eventlet doesn't yet support Python 3, so the only time this issue
     crops up is if you use eventlet on RHEL6

  4) We've fixed eventlet in EPEL6, but the issue still remains if you
     install eventlet from upstream

  5) Dave Malcolm sent a pull request to eventlet, but it has stalled:

       https://bitbucket.org/eventlet/eventlet/pull-request/30/add-dummy-timeout-parameter-to

Nova has long had a nasty workaround to patch eventlet in our virtualenv
and we now need this workaround in oslo-incubator to test processutils.
Let's add it here and make nova sync it from oslo-incubator.

I really hope we can get eventlet upstream "fixed" and the fix released
soon. When that happens, we can kill all this nastiness.

subject: Improve EC2 error response code.
commit_message:
Improve EC2 error response code.

Redundant logging code was united in new _ec2_error() helper function and all
EC2 error responses are now uniformly logged on DEBUG log level because they
are just responses to invalid client requests, not nova errors.

Proper EC2 error codes are returned where possible.

Excpetion name is used as EC2 error code instead of cryptic UnknownError in
case of unexpected error.

EC2 API specific exceptions should have EC2 suffix and contain _ (underscores)
instead of . (dots) for automatic translation which is done by new
exception_to_ec2code() function. InvalidInstanceIDMalformed was renamed to
InvalidInstanceID_MalformedEC2 in this manner.

This is a first step towards compliant or at least meaningful EC2 error codes.
Next, EC2APIError must be replaced by proper EC2 or OpenStack exceptions.

Implements blueprint ec2-error-codes
